titleStmt.title: An Excellent new Poem on the Bishops. 1731

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: By an honest Whig-Curate
Old Latimer preaching did fairly describe
A Bishop who rul'd all the rest of the tribe,
But who is this Bishop, and where does he dwell?
Why truly tw'as Satan Arch Bishop of Hell,
And he was a Primate and he wore a Miter
Surrounded with Iewells of Sulphur & niter,
How nearly this Bishop, our Bishops resembles
But his had the odds, who believes & who trembles,
Cou'd you see his grim Grace, from a pound to a penny
You'd swear it must be the Baboon of Killkenny──
Poor Satan wou'd think the Comparison odious,
I wish I cou'd find him out one more comodious,
But this I am sure, the Reverend old Dragon,
Has got on the Bench many Bishops Suffragon.
And all men believe he presides thence in-cog,
To give them in turns an invisible Iog;
Our Prelates puff'd up with wealth and with Pride,
To Hell on the Backs of the Clergy wou'd ride,
They mounted, and labour'd with whip and with spur
In vain, for the Devil a Parson wou'd stir.
So the Commons unhors'd them, & this was their doom
On their Croziers to ride, like a Witch on a broom,
Tho' they gallop'd so fast, on the Road you may find 'em
And have left us but three out of twenty behind 'em.
Lord Bolton's good Grace, Lord Carr & Lord Howard
In spight of the Devil wou'd still be untoward.
They came of good blood, and could not endure
Their former Companions, to dwell at the door.
When Christ was betray'd to Pilot the Praetor
In a Dozen Apostles, but one prov'd a Traytor.
One Traytor alone and faithfull Eleven,
But we can afford you Six Traytors in Seven
What a clutter with clippings, dividings & cleavings
And the Clergy forsooth must take up wth
their leavings.
If makeing Divisions was all their Intent,
They have done it we thank 'em, but not as they meant
And so may such Bishops for ever divide,
That no honest Heathen, wou'd be on their side.
How shou'd we rejoyce, if like Iudas the first
These Splitters of parsons, insunder shd
burst.
Now hear an Allusion. A Miter you know
Is divided above but united below,
If this you considder our Emblem is right
The Bishops divide but the Clergy unite.
Shou'd the bottom be split, our Prelates may dread
That the Miter may never stick fast to their head.
And yet they have learn'd the cheif art of a Soverg'n
As Machiavel taught 'em. Divide and you govern.
But courage My Lord, though it cannot be said
That One cloven Tongue ever sat on your head.
I'll hold you a groat, and I wish I could see it,
If your Stockings were off, you cou'd shew cloven feet.But hold cry the Bishops and give us fair play
Before you condemn us, hear what we can say.
What truer Affection cou'd ever be shewn
Than saveing your Souls, by damning our own.
And have we not practis'd all methods to gain you,
With a Tyth of a Tyth, of a Tyth to maintain you,
Provided a fund for building you spittalls.
You are only to live four Years without victualls.
Content my good Lords, and let us change hands
First take you our Tyths, and give us your Lands
So God bless the Church, and three of our Miters
And God bless the Commons for biteing the biters.803-001D
